instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used for analyzing  human skin?
Output: The related study used visible spectrum for analyzing  human skin.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used for analyzing  human skin?
Output: Hyperspectral imaging and optical-based models were used for analyzing human skin spectral features.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the neural network model for human skin, and how far can this metric go in assessing the generalization ability of the network?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the neural network model for human skin was the average deviation calculated on selected areas. This metric can assess the generalization ability of the network, showing promising results even on wide-field full-face images.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the neural network to address the issue of expensive computation cost in analyzing hyperspectral images of human skin parameters and generate skin parameter maps more quickly?
Output: The multi-layer perceptron (MLP) artificial neural network was used to address the issue of expensive computation cost in analyzing hyperspectral images of human skin parameters and generate skin parameter maps more quickly.

instruction: Can the neural network model for analyzing hyperspectral images of human skin be used to overcome the issue of expensive computation cost and generate skin parameter maps more quickly compared to traditional optimization-based algorithms?
Output: Yes, the neural network model for analyzing hyperspectral images of human skin can be used to overcome the issue of expensive computation cost and generate skin parameter maps more quickly compared to traditional optimization-based algorithms. The neural network is able to generate visually faithful skin parameter maps in as little as 2 seconds for a 3-megapixel image representing a full face and 0.5 seconds for a 1-megapixel image representing a smaller area of skin. This is a significant improvement compared to the traditional optimization-based algorithm, which requires up to 5 hours for the same task. The network's promising generalization ability, even on wide-field full-face images, makes it suitable for preview purposes, providing relatively accurate results in just a few seconds.
